title: Mindless statistics and the ‚Äònull ritual‚Äô
text:
This is the website of the workshop Mindless statistics and the ‚Äúnull ritual‚Äù, part of the STeW series (Statistical Training Workshops) of the Linguistics and English Language department of the University of Edinburgh.
The slides are linked in the main menu and you can find data and code in the GitHub repository: https://github.com/stefanocoretta/null-ritual.



Level
üü¢üü†üî¥ Any level


Description
In this workshop we will go through bad statistical practices that are common even among experienced researchers and how to avoid them. In particular, we will talk about the ‚Äúnull ritual‚Äù, which is a invalid approach to frequentist statistics commonly used in research. Most of the content of the workshop will be drawn from Gigerenzer‚Äôs Mindless Statistics paper.


Prerequisites
Some familiarity with frequentist statistics is useful but not necessary. This workshop is thought for both beginners and experienced researchers or students, whether they normally use quantitative, qualitative or mixed methods.

title: Mindless statistics and the ‚Äònull ritual‚Äô
text:
Quiz

Suppose you have a treatment that you suspect may alter performance on a certain task. You compare the means of your control and experimental groups (say 20 subjects in each sample). Further, suppose you use a simple independent means t-test and your result is signiÔ¨Åcant (t = 2.7, d.f. = 18, p = 0.01).

You have absolutely disproved the null hypothesis (that is, there is no difference between the population means).
You have found the probability of the null hypothesis being true.
You have absolutely proved your experimental hypothesis (that there is a difference between the population means).
You can deduce the probability of the experimental hypothesis being true.
You know, if you decide to reject the null hypothesis, the probability that you are making the wrong decision.
You have a reliable experimental Ô¨Ånding in the sense that if, hypothetically, the experiment were repeated a great number of times, you would obtain a signiÔ¨Åcant result on 99% of occasions.

title: Mindless statistics and the ‚Äònull ritual‚Äô
text:
The ‚Äònull ritual‚Äô

Gigerenzer (2004), Gigerenzer, Krauss & Vitouch (2004), Gigerenzer (2018).

Set up a statistical null hypothesis of ‚Äúno mean difference‚Äù or ‚Äúzero correlation.‚Äù Don‚Äôt specify the predictions of your research hypothesis or of any alternative substantive hypotheses.
Use 5% as a convention for rejecting the null. If signiÔ¨Åcant, accept your research hypothesis. Report the result as p < 0.05, p < 0.01, or p < 0.001 (whichever comes next to the obtained p-value).
Always perform this procedure.

title: Mindless statistics and the ‚Äònull ritual‚Äô
text:
Why is it problematic?

The null ritual would have been rejected by the statisticians it is attributed to.

Fisher rejected each of the steps above towards the end of his life.

‚ÄúNull‚Äù does not mean ‚Äúnil‚Äù but ‚Äúto be nullified‚Äù.
Fisher thought that using a routine 5% level of signiÔ¨Åcance indicated lack of statistical thinking.
Null hypothesis testing was the most primitive of analyses (only when no or very little knowledge.

Neyman and Pearson rejected null hypothesis testing and favoured competitive testing between two or more hypotheses.

title: Mindless statistics and the ‚Äònull ritual‚Äô
text:
Fisher‚Äôs null hypothesis testing


Set up a statistical null hypothesis. The null need not be a nil hypothesis (i.e., zero difference).
Report the exact level of signiÔ¨Åcance (e.g., p = 0.051 or p = 0.049). Do not use a conventional 5% level, and do not talk about accepting or rejecting hypotheses.
Use this procedure only if you know very little about the problem at hand.

(Gigerenzer 2004: 590)

title: Mindless statistics and the ‚Äònull ritual‚Äô
text:
Neyman‚ÄìPearson decision theory


Set up two statistical hypotheses, H1 and H2, and decide about \(\alpha\), \(\beta\), and sample size before the experiment, based on subjective cost-beneÔ¨Åt considerations. These deÔ¨Åne a rejection region for each hypothesis.
If the data falls into the rejection region of H1, accept H2; otherwise accept H1. Note that accepting a hypothesis does not mean that you believe in it, but only that you act as if it were true.
The usefulness of the procedure is limited among others to situations where you have a disjunction of hypotheses (e.g., either \(\mu_1 = 8\) or \(\mu_2 = 10\) is true) and where you can make meaningful cost-beneÔ¨Åt trade-offs for choosing alpha and beta.

(Gigerenzer 2004: 590‚Äì1)

title: Mindless statistics and the ‚Äònull ritual‚Äô
text:
Level of significance


Early Fisher

Mere convention of 5%.

Neyman and Pearson

\(\alpha\): probability of wrongly rejecting \(H_1\) (vs \(H_2\)), Type-I error

Later Fisher

Rejects idea of convention and Type-I and II errors.
Exact level of significance, i.e.¬†exact \(p\).
‚ÄúYou communicate information; you do not make yes‚Äìno decisions.‚Äù (Gigerenzer 2004: 593).
